title: 1st question from Chap.20: Combination, Permutation and Probability

body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which Of the following Company  name was on the first thing sold on FLIPKART? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: Will log accept me?
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is "},{"type":"text","text":"true","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\begin{array}{c}110 > 3 \\implies \\log 10 > \\log 3 \\implies   0 > \\log  3 -1 \\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" \nThen it  must be "},{"type":"text","text":"true","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\begin{array}{c}44 > 3 \\implies \\log 4 - 1 > \\log 3 -1 \\implies \\dfrac{\\log 4 -1}{\\log 3-1} > 1 \\,.\\end{array}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" \nIf possible try to solve without  using calculators ."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can just use the first derivation to see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log 3 - 1 < 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is negative, and if we divide both sides of
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log 4 - 1 > \log 3 - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
by a negative number, we must change the direction of the inequality, so it gives
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\log 4 - 1}{\log 3 - 1} < \frac{\log 3 - 1}{\log 3 - 1} = 1."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First 
If A+B=45° then (1+tanA)(1+tanB)=2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Prove: 
we all know that "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Tan(A+B)=(tanA+tanB)÷(1-tanAtanB)
So,tanA+tanB=tan(A+B)-tan(A+B)tanAtanB"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1+tanA)(1+tanB)
=1+tanAtanB+tanA+tanB
=1+tanAtanB+tan(A+B)-tan(A+B) tanAtanB"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Because A+B=45° so tan (A+B)=1
=1+tan(A+B)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Because A+B=45° so tan (A+B)=1
=1+1
=2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So,with the conclusion above,then rearrange the question into a(1+tanA)(1+tanB)form 
[A+B=45°]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So
(1+tan1°)(1+tan44°)(1+tan2°)(1+tan43°)×...
×(1+tan22°)(1+tan23°)=2^22=4194304"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1- Thanksgiving
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Roasting a turkey requires 15 minutes to preheat the oven. After that, it takes 12 minutes for every half kilogram of turkey. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Paula bought a turkey weighing 2.5 kg. At what time she should turn on the oven so that the turkey is ready at 8:00 pm?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For every "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac {1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" kg of Turkey, 12 minutes of roasting is required."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \dfrac {1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" kg, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 \times 12=60"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" minutes of roasting is required."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15 minutes are required to heat the oven."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Totally, 1 hour 15 minutes are required. So, To finish at 8:00 p.m, she must start at 6:45 p.m."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the function, y=x^{1/x}. Evaluate dy/dx and it turns out to be x^{(1/x)-2} (1-ln x), which when equated to zero gives x=e. 
Note that dy/dx >0 for x <e, dy/dx=0 for x=e and dy/dx <0 for x>e. Therefore the function y=x^{1/x} is a decreasing function when x>e. Hence, for x1>x2>e, x2^{1/x2} > x1^{1/x1}."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since 10>7>e, 7^(1/7) > 10^(1/10). Raisiing the power to 70 on both sides, 7^10 > 10^7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^7 = 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 = 10000000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{10} = 49^5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"282475249"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is larger."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If you know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^3 = 343"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then you can estimate that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^6 = 343^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a little greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100000 = 10^5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"With that in mind, base 10 logarithms tell us that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log(7^6)\ge\log(10^5)\;\Rightarrow\;6\log7\ge5\;\Rightarrow\;\log7\ge\frac56"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log(7^{10}) = 10\log7 \ge 10\cdot\frac56 = \frac{25}3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log(10^7) = 7 < \frac{25}3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log(10^7) < \log(7^{10})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{10} > 10^7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I'm wondering why there isn't anybody who used log to solve this:
10log7 =10x0.9..... >0.9 > 7log10=7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{10} ... 10^{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":",
= "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ... "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":",
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 343 > 10 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
So, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{10} > 10^{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^10>6^10=6^7×6^3
6^3=2^3×3^3>2^3×2^4=>2^7
Therefore, 7^10>6^10>6^7×2^7=12^7>10^7
Hence proved"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I cheated and used the fact that I have the first ten powers of 2 memorized:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4<7<8, so (4^10)<(7^10)<(8^10)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^10=(2^10)^2 or roughly 10^6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8^10=(2^10)^3 or roughly 10^9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7 is closer to 8, so 7^10 is going to be closer to 10^9 which is larger than 10^7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_1, x_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_1, x_2>e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_1>x_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_2^{x_1}>x_1^{x_2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and vice versa...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^7 ? 7^10"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 ? .7^7*7^3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1? (.7)*(3.43)^3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"70% of 3 itself is greater than 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So 1< (.7)*(3.43)^3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence 7^10 is bigger."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's put "?" for our relation."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10⁷ ? 7¹⁰
log(10⁷) ? log(7¹⁰) [apply log, which is increasing, so the "?" sign stays the same]
7.log(10) ? 10.log(7) [log property]
7 ? 10.log(7) [log(10=1)]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, log(7)>1, so, 10 log(7)>10, therefore
7 < 10.log(7) which means that "?" = "<" and then"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10⁷ < 7¹⁰"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1 to 100
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\large 1,2,3,\\ldots,100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Above shows the first 100 "},{"type":"text","text":"positive integers","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":". Find the sum of all these numbers."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+2+3+ \ldots+100\\
=\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^{100} n\\
=\dfrac{100(101)}{2}\\
=50(101)\\
=\boxed{5050}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Alternate method:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+2+3+ \ldots + 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a sum of an arithmetic progression with"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=1,\;d=1,\;n=100,\;T_n = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Apply the formula for sum of arithmetic progressions:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n = \dfrac{n}{2} (a+T_n)\\
S_{100} = \dfrac{100}{2} (1+100) = 50(101) = \boxed{5050}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The answer is easily obtained via Gauss's summation trick.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2}\times100\times101 = 5050"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1 to 12!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Twelve men are in a room, some of them always tell lies, while the others always tell the truth."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first man says:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "None of us is a truth teller.""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The second man says:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "At most one of us is a truth teller.""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The third man says:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "At most two of us are truth tellers.""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ldots......."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The twelfth and last man says:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "At most eleven of us are truth tellers.""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many of them are "},{"type":"text","text":"liars","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When using the phrase "at most", the bigger the number, the truer it becomes. So, if the twelfth man is a Knight, then the first man's statement would be inevitably became a lie. Therefore, with any additional Knight, another knave would have to appear to counter the balance.             "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Answer = 12/2 = 6 knaves."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1 to 12
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A distinct integer from 1 to 12 is placed in each red circle in the figure below. Is it possible that the sum of the four numbers on any of the six blue lines is the same? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/Qjrm0K1vV4-group-8.svg?width=400"}}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Hosam Hajjir"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/hosam-7rj67v/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" In one of my previous problems ("},{"type":"text","text":"1 to 10","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":") the figure was similar, just with a regular pentagon. The answer was "Not possible" in that problem. Can you generalize, that if we make a similar figure just with a regular polygon, with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" number of sides, for what types of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the numbering possible?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            In another possible arrangement, the inner hexagon has 8,7,3,11,6 and 1 in clockwise order and outer hexagon has 12 at the vertex closest to 8 and 7 and the remaining five numbers in clockwise order are 2,4,10,5 and 9. The sum along each of the six lines is 26.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I guess it is possible with even number of sides but not with odd number of sides

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of all numbers 1-12 equals 78. If we select 4 random numbers from this set their sum most likely will be 78/3 = 26."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now assign each circle a letter (any order you like) and write down the equations for the picture:
- A+B+C+D=sum
- E+F+G+H=sum
- E+X+B+Y=sum
- M+G+N+D=sum
- A+X+F+M=sum
- Y+C+N+H=sum"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum last 4 equations and subtract 2 first ones to find out that
- M+N+X+Y=sum also"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we have that
- A+B+C+D=sum
- E+F+G+H=sum
- M+N+X+Y=sum"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Meaning that we have to split numbers 1-12 into 3 subsets such that sums inside each subset is equal. It is possible only if sum=26."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"26 is even, and numbers 1-12 contain 6 odd and 6 even numbers, so each line should have either 2 or 4 odd numbers for the sum to be even."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Considering these 2 facts It is pretty easy to find a fitting combination."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's some Python 3 code I wrote that does it all for you:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"import itertools # for generating all permutations
eqs = ((0, 2, 4, 6), 
       (1, 2, 3, 5),
       (0, 3, 7, 10),
       (1, 4, 8, 11),
       (10, 9, 8, 6),
       (5, 7, 9, 11)) # the sums for each line



str_to_format = \
"""    {:2}      {:2}    
        {:2}        
    {:2}      {:2}    
{:2}              {:2}
    {:2}      {:2}    
        {:2}        
    {:2}      {:2}     Sum: {}\n\n\n""" # so that it looks like the picture



for i in itertools.permutations(list(range(1, 13))): #for every possible arrangement of [1,12]
    sums = []
    for eq in eqs: #for each line on the picture
        sum = 0
        for q in eq: #take the sum of that line
            sum += i[q]
        sums.append(sum)
    if sums.count(sums[0]) == len(sums): #and if they're all the same
        print(str_to_format.format(*i, sums[0])) #show me!
"}],"attrs":[{"text":"import itertools # for generating all permutations
eqs = ((0, 2, 4, 6), 
       (1, 2, 3, 5),
       (0, 3, 7, 10),
       (1, 4, 8, 11),
       (10, 9, 8, 6),
       (5, 7, 9, 11)) # the sums for each line



str_to_format = \
"""    {:2}      {:2}    
        {:2}        
    {:2}      {:2}    
{:2}              {:2}
    {:2}      {:2}    
        {:2}        
    {:2}      {:2}     Sum: {}\n\n\n""" # so that it looks like the picture



for i in itertools.permutations(list(range(1, 13))): #for every possible arrangement of [1,12]
    sums = []
    for eq in eqs: #for each line on the picture
        sum = 0
        for q in eq: #take the sum of that line
            sum += i[q]
        sums.append(sum)
    if sums.count(sums[0]) == len(sums): #and if they're all the same
        print(str_to_format.format(*i, sums[0])) #show me!
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Numbers 1,2,9 and 8 add up to 20.
Similarly numbers 7,2,6 and 5 add up to 20."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
